title.rendered: Food Swings – Stuffed Italian Sweet Peppers

content.rendered:
By Jacob Mathias

Hello fellow eaters. I hope everyone had an excellent Fourth of July holiday. We’re back again in full Food Swings. I have a treat for you today- it’s only 5 ingredients and sure to impress everybody.

It makes great a presentation and can be prepped ahead of time for speedy cooking later on.

You will need:

4 Italian sweet peppers, halved and seeded
1 lb Italian sausage
½ cup bread crumbs
½ cup shredded Romano cheese
2 cups marinara sauce.
Preheat oven to 400. Brown sausage over medium high heat. Combine with bread crumbs and cheese. Spoon sausage mixture into peppers until loosely full. Sprinkle with more cheese.
Place on an oiled baking sheet and bake for 20 minutes.
Ladle warm marinara sauce in bottom of pasta bowl and place peppers on top.

Serve with some crusty bread and a glass of red.

And remember, Live to Eat!

title.rendered: Food Swings – Bulgar Wheat Salad

content.rendered:
BY Jake Mathias

Hello, fellow eaters. Sorry I’ve been away for a while.

As of Sunday, I guess I’m on a sort of diet. Not like a real diet, but more like a “I better not order pizza at 1:00 a.m.” type of diet. In any case, it can’t hurt to eat a little healthier, at least once in a while.

The only way I can really eat healthy is if I’m eating salad. Otherwise I have absolutely no idea how to achieve the goal. Health food is beyond me in any other capacity.

I learned this recipe while I was travelling in Greece four years ago. It’s a bulgar wheat salad. Don’t let the name bulgar wheat scare you, no matter how much it sounds like vulgar. Bulgar is a great way to add grains and fiber to your diet. It has a nutty flavor and goes great as both a salad base and soup additive.

We’re going to use a few different vegetables in today’s salad, but don’t stop with what I’m going to list here. Use what’s fresh and available to you at the time. This is supposed to be a quick and easy dish.

You will need:

2 cups cold prepared bulgar wheat (see package instructions)
Juice of 2 lemons
3 tbsp olive oil
¼ cup chopped green onions
1 cucumber, peeled, seeded and diced small
2 roma tomatoes seeded and diced
3 ribs sliced celery
2 tsp kosher salt
2 tsp fresh cracked pepper

Gently combine all ingredients. Serve cold with extra lemon wedges and olive oil if needed.

And remember, Live to Eat!

title.rendered: Food Swings – Pulled Pork

content.rendered:
By Jacob Mathias

Hello fellow eaters. Spring/Summer/Road Construction Season has finally arrived. It’s time for people to come together again and commence with the feeding.

When planning a meal for a large group of people, there are few things that will make it easy. Make something you can prepare ahead of time. Make it impossible to screw up. Make it delicious.

When I have to feed a large group of people, I always choose to make pulled pork. It’s easy. It’s dirt cheap. And it requires absolutely no grace or cooking technique.

WARNING: This roast does take 12 hours. I usually place it in the oven right before bed and then retrieve it in the morning. There is nothing better than waking up with the aroma of pork fat in your nose and pillowcases.

You will need:

¼ cup Lowry’s salt
2 tbsp. black pepper
1 tbsp. garlic powder
1 tbsp. chili powder
¼ cup Maple syrup
8 lb. picnic roast.
1 cup water

Preheat oven to 250.

Trim the picnic roast of the rind but leave excess fat. Mix salt, pepper, garlic, and chili powder together and rub liberally on all sides of roast. Then, rub the top with the syrup.

Place pork on a roasting rack in a heavy pan with the water in the bottom. Place in over and forget about it for 12 hours.

When pork comes out, the meat should be fork tender and the bone should cleanly pull out of roast.

Pull pork into shreds with forks or fingers. Add half of the pan juices back into the pork for a boast of flavor.
Serve on buns with coleslaw and barbeque sauce.

And remember, Live to Eat!

title.rendered: Food Swings – Grilled Asparagus and Prosciutto Pizza

content.rendered:
By Jacob Mathias

Hello, fellow eaters. Spring is finally here and we at the City-Times have a great meal idea that combines everything I love about spring: grills, spring vegetables, and cheese.

Grilled pizza is one of my favorite foods. The smoky charred crust adds an extra oomph to your pizza that you don’t get out of the oven. Grilled pizza required a quick hand and a constant eye, but if you pay attention, you’ll deliver quite the treat for your family members.

Today we’re making a grilled pizza with asparagus, prosciutto ham and Gruyere cheese.

You will need:

1 bunch of asparagus ends trimmed
8 ounces prosciutto ham sliced thin and cut into thin strips (regular ham will work if need be)
8 ounces shredded Gruyere cheese
4 pieces of flat-bread
Olive oil
Salt and pepper

Preheat grill with low and high heat zones. If using gas, keep one side on low and the other high. If using charcoal, keep pile of briquettes to one side of the grill.

Lightly coat asparagus with olive oil and season with salt and pepper. Place asparagus stalks on hot side of grill. Carefully turn over after 3 minutes and cook another 2 minutes. Remove from grill and cut into 1 inch pieces.

Brush both sides of flat bread with olive oil. Place on low heat side of grill and cook for two minutes. Flip flat bread and top each with 2 ounces ham, 2 stalks asparagus, and 2 ounces cheese. Place lid on grill and cook for two minutes allowing cheese to melt and bread to crisp.

Serve on a porch with big pitcher of homemade sangria filled with local spring berries.

And remember, Live to Eat!

title.rendered: Food Swings: Veggie Lentil Soup

content.rendered:
By Jacob Mathias

Hello, fellow eaters. I don’t like winter; it puts me in a foul mood. Nothing keeps me from wanting to cook like cold weather, my car covered in ice, and a general dreariness that tends to consume the ever-living fiber of my being. But alas, we have to eat, and winter or not, I refuse to let my doldrums destroy your appetite so away we go.
I like soup because it’s fast, cheap, and reheats easy. Today I want to make a quick veggie lentil soup that is sure to warm you up even in this monstrosity of a season we call spring.

You will need:

1 lg. yellow onion, diced
3 stalks celery, diced
3 carrots, diced
1 tsp. chopped garlic
2 lg. tomatoes, chopped medium
4 tomatoes
2 qts. chicken stock
2 tbsp. olive oil
2 bay leaves
Salt and Pepper
¾ cup green lentils, rinsed and sorted

Sauté onion, celery, carrot and garlic in olive oil over medium high heat until onions just begin to brown. Add in chicken stock, tomatoes, lentils, and bay leaves. Bring to a low simmer, reduce heat and continue to simmer, stirring occasional until lentils are tender, about 25 minutes. Season to taste with salt and pepper.

Serve piping hot with buttered, crusty bread.

And remember, Live to Eat.

title.rendered: Food Swings – Beer Braised Short Ribs

content.rendered:
By Jacob Mathias

Hello, fellow eaters. We at the City-Times hope you all had a wonderful St. Patrick’s Day full of food, drink, and friends. Now, what to do with all my leftover beer, you ask?

Beer can add a great rich flavor to all kinds of different protein. Light beers work great to add flavor to poultry and pork while a darker beer can add deep, dense flavor to beef and lamb.

Today we’re going to make some wonderful beer braised beef short ribs.

You will need:

5 lb. beef short ribs
1 qt. beef stock
2 bottles Point 2012 Black Ale
1 red onion diced
2 tbsp. red wine vinegar
2 tsp. cracked black pepper
2 tsp. kosher salt
Olive Oil

Season short ribs with salt and pepper.

In a heavy cast iron Dutch oven or deep pot of your choosing, coat bottom of pan with olive oil and place over medium high heat. When pan is hot, add in short ribs. Brown ribs on all sides until brown and caramelized. Add in onions and cook stirring often until onions are sweating.

Preheat oven to 350.

Add in remaining ingredients except vinegar and bring to a low simmer. Cover pot and place in oven for 3 hours adding water as needed to keep moist.

Remove from oven and add in vinegar to brighten up all the flavors.

Serve short ribs with some crusty yeast bread, perhaps from The Main Grain Bakery.

Enjoy and remember, Live to Eat!

excerpt.rendered: By Jacob Mathias Hello, fellow eaters. We at the City-Times hope you all had a wonderful St. Patrick’s Day full of food, drink, and friends. Now, what to do with all my leftover beer, you ask?

title.rendered: Food Swings: Chicken with Kale and Chili Peanut Sauce

content.rendered:
By Jacob Mathias
Hello, fellow eaters. Winter wears on, and even though it’s just the beginning of March, that doesn’t mean we can’t cook something awesome delicious to celebrate the upcoming start of spring and longer days.

Today we are going to prepare a delicious chicken recipe with a spicy peanut sauce and braised kale.

You will need:

2 boneless, skinless chicken breasts
4 tbsp. olive oil
1 tbsp. sesame oil
1 tsp. chopped garlic
6 green onions chopped small
¾ cup chopped Spanish peanuts
salt and pepper
2 tbsp. chili paste
1 qt. chicken stock
1 gallon kale leaves

Preheat oven to 350.

Season chicken with salt and pepper and cook in 1 tbsp. olive oil in a sauté pain over medium heat. Cook 5 minutes on each side so the chicken is golden brown.

While the chicken is cooking, heat 3 tbsp. olive oil and sesame oil over medium heat in a sauté pan. Add garlic. When garlic become fragrant, add in chili paste, green onions and peanuts.

Pour peanut mixture over chicken and put in oven for 15-20 minutes, until the chicken reaches and internal temperature of 160 degrees.

While chicken is cooking in the oven, heat chicken stock mixed with 1 tbsp. chili paste over high heat to a low simmer. Add in kale and cover. Cook the kale for 12 minutes. Stirring every few minutes.

Drain the kale and place in a shallow serving dish. Top with the chicken breasts and peanut sauce mixture.
Enjoy!

And remember, Live to Eat!

title.rendered: Food Swings – Whiskey Pepper Cream Sauce

content.rendered:
Hello again, fellow eaters. After a week of bad weather and more of blistering cold that makes you cuss at the mere thought of going outside, we’re going to make something special that is sure to impress both those you are feeding as well as yourself. Your guest will be blown away by your technique and you’ll be blown away at how easy the actual cooking was.

Today we are going to make beef tenderloin with a reduced whisky pepper cream pan sauce. If tenderloin isn’t quite in your budget, a ribeye, or sirloin will do the trick just as well. You can even pour the sauce on pot roast if you really want to. It’s a great combo with beef of all shapes and sizes.

You will need:

2 6 oz. beef tenderloins (feel free to wrap in bacon if you’re feeling especially gluttonous)
Olive Oil
Kosher salt and fresh cracked pepper to taste
1 tbsp. butter
¼ cup finely diced shallot (an onion will do in a pinch
1.5 ounces Crown Royal Black Canadian Whiskey (I like to use the single serving bottles so I don’t have to measure)
¾ cup heavy cream

Begin by heating the olive oil over medium heat in a heavy sauté pan. Season your beef with salt and pepper and place in pan, cooking for 7 minutes. Flip beef and cook an additional 5 minutes. (This is for medium rare. Adjust timing for your preference.)

Remove steaks from pan. Add butter and onions into pan and cook until edges of onions are lightly browned. Slowly pour in the whiskey. If using a gas stove, remove pan from flames before adding in. Simmer until whiskey is reduced by about half. Add in cream, ½ teaspoon of salt, and 1.5 teaspoons of pepper and simmer until reduced by about a third. Spoon sauce over steaks.

Serve with some crusty bread for mopping up the sauce and beef juices.

And remember, Live to Eat!

title.rendered: Food Swings- Ditch The Box: 10 Easy Pancake Recipes

content.rendered:
Left, Chocolate Chip Pancakes made from scratch. (City-Times photo)

Compiled by City-Times Staff

1. Basic Pancakes Whisk 1 1/2 cups flour, 3 tablespoons sugar, 1 tablespoon baking powder and 1/2 teaspoon salt. Whisk 1 1/4 cups milk, 1/2 stick melted butter,2 eggs and a little vanilla, then whisk into the flour mixture until just combined. Ladle 1/4 cupfuls onto a hot buttered skillet and cook until bubbly. Flip and cook until golden on the bottom.

2. Blueberry Pancakes Make Basic Pancakes (No. 1); sprinkle with blueberries before flipping.

3. Chocolate-Chip Pancakes Make Basic Pancakes (No. 1); sprinkle with chocolate chips before flipping.

4. Whole-Wheat Pancakes Make Basic Pancakes (No. 1) with 3/4 cup each all-purpose and whole-wheat flour. Top with chopped almonds and berries.

5. Corn Cakes Make Basic Pancakes (No. 1) with just 1/2 cup flour; add 1 cup yellow cornmeal with the flour. Top with honey.

6. Blue Corn Cakes Make Basic Pancakes (No. 1) with just 1/2 cup flour; add 1 cup blue cornmeal with the flour. Top with dried apricots warmed in honey.

7. Oat Pancakes Make Basic Pancakes (No. 1) with just 3/4 cup flour; add 1/2 cup ground oats and 1/4 cup wheat germ with the flour.

8. Lemon-Strawberry Cakes Make Basic Pancakes (No. 1) with just 1/2 cup milk. Add 1 cup cottage cheese and 2 teaspoons grated lemon zest with the milk. Top with strawberries and honey.

9. Blini Make Basic Pancakes (No. 1) or Buttermilk Pancakes (No. 13) with 3/4 cup each all-purpose and buckwheat flour; omit the butter. Cook by tablespoonfuls. Serve with sour cream, smoked salmon and chives.

10. Berry-Topped Pancakes Toss 3 cups mixed berries with 2 tablespoons sugar and 1 tablespoon lemon juice; let sit while you make Basic Pancakes (No. 1). Top the pancakes with the berries and their juices.

title.rendered: Food Swings: Sunday Brunch- Chorizo & Egg Dish

content.rendered:
For the City-Times

This scrumptious egg dish is so easy because it’s a one- pan affair, simple for any skill level.  Just brown the chorizo, fry the eggs in the same pan and mix in the cream and goat cheese and bake.  It’s perfect on its own, or served over a grilled baguette, English Muffin or toast, and garnished with some greens.

Ingredients

  • 3 Eggs
  • 2 Ounce heavy  cream
  • 4 Ounce goat  cheese, separated in half and crumbled
  • 6 Ounce fresh  chorizo (D’artagnan brand preferred) sliced on a bias about .25 of an inch
  • 5 Leaves of  baby arugula
  • 3 Sprigs  frisee heart (yellow part)
  • 3 slices of  baguette
  • Salt to  taste
  • Piment  d’espelette to taste
  • 1 Ounce soy  oil
  • 8-inch iron  skillet

Preparation

Step 1:

Place iron skillet over med heat.

Step 2:

Add 1 oz. of oil to the skillet

Step 3:

Add sliced chorizo to the pan and brown slightly the chorizo will release  some of its own fat into the oil making it a “chorizo oil” it should be a  beautiful red color. Remove chorizo and oil from the pan and reserve.

Step 4:

Place pan back on med heat and crack the three eggs directly into it. The  eggs should sizzle a bit.

Step 5:

Now pour in the heavy cream around the eggs

Step 6:

Add half the goat Cheese around the eggs along with chorizo.

Step 7:

Place in an oven that is pre-heated to 375 ° until the whites are set.

Step 8:

Remove from the oven remember that the pan is hot so be careful where you  place it.

Step 9:

Add the rest of the goat cheese sprinkle with salt and piment  d’espelette.

Step 10:

Garnish with the baby arugula and frisee sprigs.

Step 11:

Spoon some of the left over chorizo oil all over the eggs.

Step 12:

Grill the baguette or warm it in the oven and enjoy!

excerpt.rendered: For the City-Times This scrumptious egg dish is so easy because it’s a one- pan affair, simple for any skill level.

title.rendered: Food Swings – Beer Dip

content.rendered:
By Jacob Mathias

Hello, fellow eaters. Super Bowl Sunday, one of the biggest ‘food holidays’ of the year is just around the corner, and we have some more awesome treats you can whip up for your party or food buffet.

Let’s make some beer dip. It combines Wisconsin’s favorite foods: cheese and beer.

You will need:

16 ounces softened cream cheese
1 packet ranch dressing mix
1/2 cup Point Amber beer
2 cups shredded cheddar cheese
1/2 cup roasted red peppers diced
1 tsp. cracked black pepper
Pretzels

Using a mixer, combine cream cheese, beer, ranch seasoning, pepper and cheddar cheese. Mix on medium speed until well combined and smooth. Add in beer and mix until well combined. Add red peppers and fold in slowly.

Serve with thick pretzels for dipping.

And remember, Live to Eat!

title.rendered: Food Swings – Bleu Cheese & Bacon Stuffed Mushrooms

content.rendered:
By Jacob Mathias

Hello, fellow eaters. The end of January is nigh which means Super Bowl season is upon us. Time to break out the hardcore dips, the food on a stick, and a stack of beer as tall as I am (6’1” if you’re asking).

My favorite game snack is a stuffed mushroom. It’s easy to eat with a toothpick (one of the major components of game time food), delicious, and can be prepared in about 20,000 ways. Although we’ll just do one preparation today.

You will need:

2 lbs. large forest mushrooms (may be labeled as stuffing mushrooms)
½ cup bleu cheese crumbles
½ cup bread crumbs
½ cup crumbled, cooked bacon
1 shallot, minced
3 tbsp. olive oil
1 tsp. salt
2 tsp. black pepper

Preheat oven to 400.

Using a spoon, carefully scoop stems out of mushrooms. Rinse mushrooms and toss in 1 tbsp. olive oil until coated. Place in a greased baking dish, top side down.

In a separate bowl, combine bleu cheese, bread crumbs, bacon, shallots, remaining olive oil, salt and pepper and mix until well combined.

Place a heaping spoonful of stuffing mixture into each mushroom cap. Place and oven and bake for 15-20 minutes until tops of mushrooms are golden brown.

Enjoy with an ice cold beer and a side of bratwurst.

And remember, live to eat.

title.rendered: Food Swings – Spicy Mushroom Noodle Soup

content.rendered:
By Jacob Mathias

Hello, fellow eaters. It’s now officially winter and cold is upon us. While it’s cold and wet outside, let’s take some steam and spice inside for a belly-warming, quick, and easy as pie soup that’s sure to please the taste buds and the wallet as we all recover from our holiday debts.

You will need:
1 lb. sliced baby portabella or mixed mushrooms
4 tbsp. sesame oil
Salt and Pepper
2 qts. chicken stock
2 packages ramen noodles (throw away the seasoning packet)
2 tbsp. soy sauce
1 ½ tbsp. chili sauce
¼ cup chopped green onions

Season the mushrooms with salt and pepper and saute in the olive oil. When the mushrooms are lightly browned, add stock, soy sauce, and chili sauce. Bring to a high simmer. Add in ramen noodles and cook until tender. Ladle into bowls and sprinkle with the green onions. Serve piping hot.

And remember, Live to Eat.

title.rendered: Food Swings – Shrimp and Grits

content.rendered:
By Jacob Mathias

Hello, fellow eaters. Do we have a treat for you today! As I rummaged through my freezer the other day, I happened upon a bag of shrimp that I’ve been ignoring for a while now; I was sick of all my shrimpy mainstays and wasn’t sure what to do with them.

I decided to test my boundaries and go ‘Southern’ (with a Yankee twist, of course!). It might not pass muster below the Mason- Dixon, but my experiment was a success in my household. I hope you enjoy it!

You will need:
1 lb. 25-29 peeled and deveined shrimp
½ lb diced bacon
6 green onions
½ cups grits
1 tsp. tabasco sauce
½ tsp. garlic powder
½ tsp. onion powder
4 oz. mild shredded cheddar
Salt and Pepper to taste
2 ¼ cup water
Cook bacon until almost crispy over medium high heat. While bacon is cooking, add grits to boiling water and stir often until grits are thick and creamy. Add in garlic, onion powder, tabasco, cheese, salt and pepper stirring until cheese is melted in and smooth.
Lower heat under bacon to medium and add in shrimp and onions. Cook until shrimp are done and remove from heat. Spoon shrimp onto a bowl of cheesy grits and enjoy.
And remember, Live to Eat!

title.rendered: Food Swings: Fried Bread

content.rendered:
City-Times Staff

Hello, dear readers. This week we’re highlighting a very simple recipe that can easily be used with leftover Christmas Ham/Turkey and gravy, dished out with any number of toppings, or served by itself: fried bread.

It’s been a long- loved staple in households during times of strife when the cupboard was a little more bear than normal, due to its versatility, cheap cost and one only needs staple items found in every home to make it. It’s also perfect for cold winter mornings!

You will need:

  • 4 teaspoons baking powder
  • 2 cups flour
  • 1 cup water
  • oil or lard (for frying)

Directions:

 

Mix flour and baking powder. Add water to make a soft dough. Pat dough out on a sheet of plastic wrap to about 1/2″ thick.

Heat up about 1/4″ of oil or lard to medium heat in a cast iron or non stick pan.

Cut dough into about 9 biscuits.

Fry on one side until brown. Flip and cook about 2-3 minutes more. Test for doneness by flaking the side of a biscuit with a fork. If it seems dry inside it is done.

Can be served with butter and jam, or be napped with gravy and served with stewed hamburger and onions, turkey and stuffing or ham and pineapple.

This is also tastes great when sprinkled with a cinnamon/sugar mix, or powdered sugar, or covered with ice cream as a treat.

excerpt.rendered: City-Times Staff Hello, dear readers. This week we’re highlighting a very simple recipe that can easily be used with leftover Christmas Ham/Turkey and gravy, dished out with any number of toppings, or served by itself: fried bread.

title.rendered: Mini Cheesecakes

content.rendered:
Hello Food Swing Readers! Here’s a great recipe for a snow day- most of you will have all these ingredients in your home already. It’s simple, cheap and yummy: prefect for any lazy day around the house with the kids.
You will need:
1 package (12 oz) vanilla wafers (or graham crackers)
2 packages cream cheese
3/4 c white sugar
2 eggs
1 t vanilla
1 can cherry pie filling
Cupcake pan (regular or miniature)
Cupcake liners

Directions
  1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).  Insert cupcake liners into your pan.
  2. Crush the vanilla wafers, and place 1/2 teaspoon of the crushed vanilla wafers into each paper cup.
  3. In a mixing bowl, beat cream cheese, sugar, eggs and vanilla until light and fluffy.  Spoon your mixture into each liner, until it’s nearly full (these won’t rise much during the baking process)
  4. Bake for 15 minutes.  Cool.  Top with a teaspoonful of cherry pie filling.
  5. Enjoy!

title.rendered: Food Swings – Prime Rib

content.rendered:
By Jacob Mathias

Hello, fellow eaters. I hope everyone’s holiday season is off to great start. All the shopping is done, all the presents wrapped and all the trees are trimmed.

As great as that would be, we all know that if it’s not down to the wire, nothing holiday-like is going to be finished with any haste.

In an attempt to help you save some time over your holiday, we’ll plan some holiday meals for you. That way, you’ll save time, energy, and internet searches for the perfect prime rib recipe.

Speaking of prime rib, that’s what we’re cooking this week.

You will need:

1 prime rib roast (approximately 1 pound per person being served.
2 tbsps. rosemary
2 tbsps. thyme
1 tbsp. season salt
1 tbsp. black pepper
1 tbsp. chopped garlic
½ cup Worcestershire sauce

Preheat oven to 400 degrees. Combine spices with Worcestershire sauce into a loose paste. Rub liberally over prime rib roast. Place the roast on a rack in a heavy roasting pan. Bake in oven for 2 hours, or until internal temperature of prime rib is at 130 degrees.

Allow prime rib to set for at least one hour before slicing.

Combine pan juices with 2 quarts beef stock to make au jus and heat in a sauce pan over medium heat to a low simmer. Place sliced prime rib in au jus and heat for 1 minute.

Serve with a cup of au jus on the side for dipping.

And remember, live to eat. Happy Holidays.

title.rendered: Four Foot Gingerbread House Brings Christmas Cheer to Hotel

content.rendered:
By Jacob Mathias

A four foot tall gingerbread house stands in the lobby of the Stevens Point Holiday Inn and Convention Center filling the room with Christmas colors and sugary smells.

The construction of the gingerbread house was head by Amber Grill Sous Chef Stephen MacNeal who has been working at Amber Grill for over 4 years and cooking for over half his life.

“This the second gingerbread house I’ve ever made in my life,” said MacNeal.  “I think I made one when I was in eight grade.”

The gingerbread house was inspired by the Holiday Inn director of sales who worked on a similar project at a hotel in Colorado.

“Originally it was going to be a larger structure.  The goal is to have that large structure within the next couple years and have Santa Claus sit in front of it,” said MacNeal.

MacNeal said he spent five hours one afternoon rolling out gingerbread dough and a total of 35 hours constructing the house itself with other staff members contributing five to seven hours each.

“I’ve never made that much royal icing before,” said MacNeal whose batch of icing was 38 pounds.

A model railroad circles the house.  The train was designed and assembled by local model railroader Phil Gjevre for the purposes of the house.

“For next year I’m going to build something a little bit more elaborate,” said MacNeal.

The ingredients that make up the house are:

38 cups flour
8 cups lard
4 tbsp cinnamon
8 tbsp ginger
4 tbsp baking soda
4 tbsp salt
4 cups molasses
20 whole eggs
220 egg whites
2 lbs granulated sugar
90 lbs confectioners sugar
10 lemons, freshly squeezed
Various cookies and candies for decorating

title.rendered: Quite Possibly the Best Gingerbread Cookie Recipe Ever

content.rendered:
*From a Swiss grandmother of one City-Times staff member

  • 3 cups all-purpose flour
  • 1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder
  • 3/4 teaspoon baking soda
  • 1/4 teaspoon salt
  • 1 tablespoon ground ginger
  • 1 3/4 teaspoons ground cinnamon
  • 1/4 teaspoon ground cloves
  • 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
  • 3/4 cup dark brown sugar
  • 1 large egg
  • 1/2 cup molasses
  • 2 teaspoons vanilla
  • 1 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest (optional)

Directions:

In a small bowl, whisk together flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, ginger, cinnamon, and cloves until well blended.

In a large bowl (KitchenAid’s great for this) beat butter, brown sugar, and egg on medium speed until well blended.

Add molasses, vanilla, and lemon zest and continue to mix until well blended.

Gradually stir in dry ingredients until blended and smooth.

Divide dough in half and wrap each half in plastic and let stand at room temperature for at least 2 hours or up to 8 hours.

(Dough can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 4 days, but in this case it should be refrigerated. Return to room temp before using.) Preheat oven to 375°.

Grease or line cookie sheets with parchment paper.

Place 1 portion of the dough on a lightly floured surface.

Sprinkle flour over dough and rolling pin.

Roll dough to a scant 1/4-inch thick.

Use additional flour to avoid sticking.

Cut out cookies with desired cutter– the ginger bread man is our favorite of course.

Space cookies 1 1/2-inches apart.

Bake 1 sheet at a time for 7-10 minutes (the lower time will give you softer cookies– very good!).

Remove cookie sheet from oven and allow the cookies to stand until the cookies are firm enough to move to a wire rack.

After cookies are cool you may decorate them any way you like.

I usually brush them with a powdered sugar glaze when I am in a hurry, but they look wonderful decorated with Royal icing.

excerpt.rendered: *From a Swiss grandmother of one City-Times staff member 3 cups all-purpose flour 1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder 3/4 teaspoon baking soda 1/4 teaspoon salt 1 tablespoon ground ginger 1 3/4 teaspoons ground cinnamon 1/4 teaspoon ground cloves 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 3/4 cup dark brown sugar 1 large egg 1/2 cup molasses 2 teaspoons vanilla 1 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest (optional)

title.rendered: Food Swings-Thanksgiving Turkey

content.rendered:
By Jacob Mathias

Hello, fellow eaters.  Every food lovers favorite holiday is just around the corner.  We all get a chance to eat as much as we want and then we get to take a nap.  As it turns out, the Thanksgiving turkey puts us to sleep as much as the fifth helping of potatoes and seventh piece of pie does so in an effort to have the best nap possible, we’re going to make the bestTurkeypossible.

You will need:

1 Turkey
6 Bay Leaves
1 tbsp. peppercorns
½ cup brown sugar
1 cup kosher salt
1 onion sliced
1 gallon chicken stock
1 gallon heavily iced water
3 sprigs fresh thyme
3 sprigs fresh rosemary

Remove the giblets from the turkey and set aside for gravy if wanted.
In a large pot, bring the stock to a boil and add in bay leaves, peppercorns, salt, sugar, thyme, and onion and boil for 10 minutes.  Remove from heat and allow to cool slightly.  Combine the stock mixture and ice water in a five gallon bucket.  Place the turkey in the bucket breast side down until completely submerged; weigh down the turkey if needed.  Cover and refrigerate for 8-16 hours, turning the turkey once.  This process is called brining and it creates a juicy, flavorful turkey.

After brining, remove turkey from bucket and pat dry.  Stuff the turkey with whatever stuffing you’d like and rub the outside with peanut or canola oil if you have an allergy.  Place on a roasting rack and roast for 4 hours at 350 degrees or until the internal temperature of the turkey reaches 160 degrees.

Remove turkey from oven and cover with aluminum foil and allow to rest for 10 minutes before carving.

Have a happy Thanksgiving everyone and remember, Live to Eat.
